mainlistitem.title: Unit 1: It's across from the library.

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Simon Tompkins. Hello, Simon.
Simon: Hi, Kathy.
Kathy: Simon, last week you visited Princeton, New Jersey.
Simon: Yes, I got back yesterday.
Kathy: What's Princeton like? I've never been there.

Simon: Princeton University has a very beautiful campus. There are lots of trees and some very old buildings. The oldest building is two hundred and fifty years old. It's located at the main entrance to the campus, on Nassau Street.
Kathy: What's the name of the building?
Simon: Nassau Hall. The office of the university president is in Nassau Hall.

comprehensionitem.question: What university did Simon visit last week?
How old is the oldest building on campus?
What is in Nassau Hall?
option: the office of the university president
comprehensionitem.answer: the office of the university president

grammaritem.question: Princeton University has a _____ beautiful campus.
The _____ building is two hundred and fifty years old.
Nassau Hall is _____ at the main entrance to the campus.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Simon Tompkins. What were you doing in Princeton?
Simon: I gave a lecture on "The Art of Photography."
Kathy: Was your lecture at the art museum?
Simon: No, it wasn't. It was in the library.
Kathy: Is the library near the art museum?

Simon: It's not very far. The art museum is in the center of campus, behind Nassau Hall. The library is in the northeast corner of campus. It's at the intersection of Nassau Street and Washington Road.
Kathy: What did you do after the lecture?
Simon: I went to the Student Center for coffee with some students. The Student Center is next to the library. It's between the library and Nassau Hall.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0501B_Q1.mp3|Where did Simon give his lecture?
NDE0501B_Q2.mp3|Which building is in the center of campus, behind Nassau Hall?
NDE0501B_Q3.mp3|What did Simon do after the lecture?
option: He went to the Student Center.
comprehensionitem.answer: He went to the Student Center.

grammaritem.answer: The library is in the northeast corner of campus.
The Student Center is next to the library.
Is the library near the art museum?

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: What's the town of Princeton like?
Simon: Oh, it's a small town. The main street is Nassau Street. There are a lot of small stores on Nassau Street, across from the campus. And some very nice restaurants and coffee houses.
Kathy: Is there a movie theater in Princeton?
Simon: Yes, there's a movie theater on Nassau Street, directly across from the library.

comprehensionitem.question: What size town is Princeton?
Are there any restaurants in Princeton?
option: Yes, there are several, but they're not very nice.

comprehensionitem.question: Where is the movie theater?

grammaritem.question: _____ the town of Princeton like?
________ a movie theater in Princeton?
_______ a movie theater directly across from the library.

mainlistitem.desc: What kinds of jobs do they have?
mainlistitem.title: Unit 2: What kinds of jobs do they have?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Sandra Harris. Sandra, I'd like to ask you a few questions about your children, Collette and John.
Sandra: Sure, go ahead.
Kathy: Do Collette and John work in the summer, when they're not in school?
Sandra: Yes, they both have part-time jobs.
Kathy: What kind of jobs do they have? Where do they work?
Sandra: Well, for example, last summer, John worked at a movie theater.
Kathy: What did he do?
Sandra: He sold tickets, and sometimes he sold popcorn and soda.
Kathy: What did Collette do? What did she do last summer?
Sandra: She worked in a restaurant. She was a waitress.
Kathy: What kind of restaurant was it?
Sandra: It was a French restaurant.

comprehensionitem.question: What kind of jobs do Collette and John have in the summer?
option: They don't have jobs in the summer.

comprehensionitem.question: What did John do last summer?
option: He worked in a movie theater.
comprehensionitem.answer: He worked in a movie theater.

comprehensionitem.question: What did Collette do last summer?

grammaritem.question: Do Collette and John ____ in the summer?
What kinds of jobs __________?
What ___ Collette do last summer?

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Sandra Harris. We're talking about summer jobs. Are John and Collette going to have jobs this summer?
Sandra: I think so. Collette's going to work in a department store. She's going to sell children's clothing.
Kathy: Where is the store?
Sandra: It's in downtown Miami, near the Convention Center.
Kathy: What about John? What's he going to do?
Sandra: In July, he's going to work at a park near our house. He's going to teach sports to children.
Kathy: And August? What's he going to do in August?
Sandra: In August, he's going to work in a fast food restaurant near our house. He's going to make hamburgers and French fries.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0502B_Q1.mp3|What's Collette going to do this summer?
option: She's going to work in a department store.
She's going to work at a park.
comprehensionitem.answer: She's going to work in a department store.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0502B_Q2.mp3|When is John going to teach sports?
NDE0502B_Q3.mp3|What's John going to do in August?
option: He's going to work in a fast food restaurant.
He's going to teach sports to children.
He's going to go back to school.
comprehensionitem.answer: He's going to work in a fast food restaurant.

grammaritem.answer: Are John and Collette going to have jobs this summer?
He's going to teach sports to children.
What's John going to do in August?

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Sandra, did you have a summer job when you were in high school?

Sandra: Yes, I usually did. One summer I worked in the public library. And another summer, I worked in a drug store. I was a sales clerk. I sold toothpaste, shampoo, and so on. I didn't like that job.

comprehensionitem.question: Did Sandra work during the summer when she was in high school?
Where did Sandra work as a sales clerk?
How did she feel about her summer job?
option: She liked it most of the time.

grammaritem.question: Did you have a summer job when you _____ in high school?
One summer I _____ in the public library.
I sold toothpaste, shampoo, _____.

mainlistitem.desc: There are pictures on the walls.
mainlistitem.title: Unit 3: There are pictures on the walls.

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Sara Scott. Sara is a doctor at a large hospital in Chicago Hello, Sara. You work mostly with children, don't you?
Sara: That's right. Most of my patients are children.
Kathy: Is your hospital only for children?

Sara: No, it isn't. It's a very large hospital. But the fourth floor of the hospital is only for children. The rooms look like children's rooms. There are funny pictures on the walls. And there are colorful curtains on the windows. Sometimes there are even pictures on the ceilings.
Kathy: Why are there pictures on the ceilings?
Sara: So that the children can look at the pictures when they are lying in their beds. We want our children to feel comfortable.

comprehensionitem.question: What kind of patient does Sara mostly work with?
Which floor of the hospital is for children?
In the children's rooms, where are the funny pictures?

grammaritem.question: _____ are colorful curtains on the windows.
Why ___ there pictures on the ceilings?
We want ___ children to feel comfortable.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Sara Scott. She's talking about the children's floor at her hospital. Sara, can parents visit their children in the hospital?

Sara: Of course, they can. Parents can visit their children any time, day or night. There are extra beds in the children's rooms so that their parents can sleep there. And there is a kitchen so that parents can cook food for their children.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0503B_Q1.mp3|When can the children's parents visit?
NDE0503B_Q2.mp3|Where can the parents sleep?
option: on a different floor of the hospital
Parents can't spend night in the hospital.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0503B_Q3.mp3|Why is there a kitchen on the children's floor of the hospital?
option: So that parents can cook food for their children.
So that parents can cook food for themselves.
So that the hospital can have a restaurant.
comprehensionitem.answer: So that parents can cook food for their children.

grammaritem.answer: Can parents visit their children in the hospital?
There are extra beds in the children's rooms.
There is a kitchen so that parents can cook food.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Is there a school at the hospital?
Sara: No, there isn't a school. But there is a teacher so that the children get some help with their school work.
Kathy: Is there a place for the children to play?
Sara: Yes, there is a playroom for the children so that they can play games together. Children need to play, and exercise helps the children get better.

comprehensionitem.question: Is there a school at the hospital?
option: No, there isn't, but there is a teacher.
Yes, there is. There is a school for sick children.
No, there isn't. There aren't any teachers at the hospital.
comprehensionitem.answer: No, there isn't, but there is a teacher.

comprehensionitem.question: Where can the children play?
option: There is a playroom for the children.
There is a gym in the basement of the hospital.
comprehensionitem.answer: There is a playroom for the children.

comprehensionitem.question: What helps the children get better?

grammaritem.question: There is a teacher _______ the children get help with their school work.
Is there a place for the children _______?
There __ a playroom for the children.

lessonitem.name: Lesson Bonus
lessonitem.title: Lesson Bonus
viewscript: Kent: This is Kent Moss, New Dynamic English Man on the Street. Today, I'm standing in front of the Washington Monument.
Carl: Excuse me.
Kent: Yes?
Carl: I need directions.
Kent: Certainly. Where do you need to go?
Carl: To the National Gallery of Art.
Kent: The National Gallery... let me see. It's right next to the Natural History Museum.
Carl: The Natural History Museum?
Kent: Yes. That's where they have the dinosaur bones.
Carl: I'm afraid I don't know where that is.
Kent: Okay... well, it's across the street from the Air and Space Museum. You know, where they have the Wright Brothers' airplane.
Carl: I don't know where that is, either.
Kent: Is this your first visit to Washington, D.C.?
Carl: Actually.. I live here!
Kent: OK. Come with me. I'll show you where it is.

comprehensionitem.question: Where does the man want to go?
option: to the Air and Space Museum

comprehensionitem.question: What is next to the National Gallery of Art?
Where does the man live?
option: He doesn't live in the United States.

grammaritem.question: It's right ____ to the Natural History Museum.
It's across the street ____ the Air and Space Museum.
Is this ____ first visit to Washington, D.C.?

mainlistitem.desc: We're going to rent a motorhome.
mainlistitem.title: Unit 4: We're going to rent a motorhome.

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Bob Harris. Next summer, you're going to Alaska with your family.
Bob: That's right. We're going to take the ferry from Seattle to Anchorage, Alaska. And then we're going to drive around Alaska for a week.
Kathy: Are you going to rent a car?
Bob: No, we're going to rent a motorhome.
Kathy: A motorhome?
Bob: Yes. Some people call them RV's -recreational vehicles.
Kathy: Why are you going to rent a motorhome? Isn't it expensive?

Bob: Not really. When you travel by car, you have to stay in motels. Motels are expensive. When you travel in a motorhome, you don't have to pay for motels. You can sleep in the motorhome. And the motorhome has a kitchen, so we can cook our own meals. We can save a lot of money, because we don't have to eat at restaurants.
Kathy: Sounds like a great idea for a vacation, Bob.

comprehensionitem.question: How are Bob and his family going to travel around Alaska?
option: They're going to rent a motorhome.
They're going to rent a car.
They're going to drive to Alaska.
comprehensionitem.answer: They're going to rent a motorhome.

comprehensionitem.question: Where will Bob and his family sleep?
option: They are going to sleep in the motorhome.
They are going to stay in motels.
They are going to go camping.
comprehensionitem.answer: They are going to sleep in the motorhome.

comprehensionitem.question: How will Bob and his family save money on food?
option: They are going to cook their own meals.
They are going to eat in inexpensive restaurants.
They are going to bring their own food.
comprehensionitem.answer: They are going to cook their own meals.

grammaritem.question: Why are you going ______ a motorhome?
When you travel by car, you ______ stay in motels.
We can save a lot of money, ______ we don't have to eat at restaurants.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: How big is a motorhome, Bob?
Bob: We're going to get one that is twenty-two feet long. It has a kitchen, a bathroom, a dining area, and four beds.
Kathy: Really! All those rooms in a motorhome?
Bob: Yes! The door is on the side of the motorhome, near the back. When you come in, the kitchen is in front of you. There's a sink... and a stove....
Kathy: Where's the refrigerator?
Bob: The refrigerator is next to the door, on your right.
Kathy: And the bathroom?
Bob: The bathroom is on your left.
Kathy: When you say "bathroom," do you mean the toilet?
Bob: Well, there's a toilet and a sink, but there's also a shower. There isn't a bathtub, so you can't take a bath, but you can take a shower.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0504B_Q1.mp3|Where is the door to the motorhome?
option: on the side, near the back
There are two doors, one on each side.
comprehensionitem.answer: on the side, near the back

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0504B_Q2.mp3|What is in front of you when you enter the motorhome?
NDE0504B_Q3.mp3|What doesn't the motorhome have?

grammaritem.answer: The door is on the side of the motorhome, near the back.
The refrigerator is next to the door, on your right.
There isn't a bathtub, so you can't take a bath.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Bob Harris. He's telling us about the motorhome that he's going to rent next summer. You said there are four beds. Where are they?
Bob: They're near the front of the motorhome. There's one big bed. Two people can sleep there. And there's a sofa bed and one more small bed.
Kathy: It sounds like a fun way to travel.

comprehensionitem.question: How many beds does the motorhome have?
Are the beds in the front of the motorhome or in the back?
option: Two are in the front, and two are in the back.

comprehensionitem.question: How many people can sleep in the big bed?

grammaritem.question: The ____ are near the front of the motorhome.
Two people can _____ in the big bed.
It _____ like a fun way to travel.

mainlistitem.title: Unit 5: The sun is a circle.

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Jenny Chen. How are you today?
Jenny: Fine.
Kathy: Jenny, tell us a little about your son.
Jenny: Jason.... Well, he likes to draw pictures. It's something we like to do together. First I draw a circle, a square, or some other shape. And then Jason draws a picture with that shape.
Kathy: Can you give us an example?
Jenny: Sure. Last night I drew a circle on a piece of paper. And I asked Jason, "What is it?"
Kathy: What did he say?
Jenny: He said, "It's the sun."
Kathy: Yes, the sun is a circle.
Jenny: And then he drew a tree and some flowers. And he made a picture of a sunny day.

comprehensionitem.question: What does Jenny's son like to do?
What shape did Jenny draw for her son last night?
What did Jason think the shape looked like?

grammaritem.question: First I draw a circle, a square, or some other _____.
Last night I ____ a circle on a piece of paper.
Then Jason made a picture of a _____ day.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Jenny Chen. We're talking about the pictures that her son Jason drew. Can Jason draw other pictures with circles?
Jenny: Well, for example, this morning he drew a picture of a mouse.
Kathy: A mouse?
Jenny: Yes. He drew a big circle for the head. Then he drew two circles next to each other - inside the big circle.
Kathy: Those were the eyes?
Jenny: That's right. Those were the eyes. Then he drew a small circle for the nose, under the eyes. Then he drew a mouth below the nose.
Kathy: And what about the ears?
Jenny: He drew a circle on each side of the head. Those were the ears.
Kathy: You can make a lot of pictures with circles, can't you?
Jenny: Yes. A circle can be a clock, or a balloon, or a basketball.
Kathy: Or a cookie. Mmm, I'm getting hungry.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0505B_Q1.mp3|What did Jason draw?
NDE0505B_Q2.mp3|Jason drew a circle on each side of the head. What were they?
NDE0505B_Q3.mp3|What else can you draw with a circle?

grammaritem.answer: We're talking about the pictures that her son Jason drew.
This morning he drew a picture of a mouse.
He drew a small circle for the nose, under the eyes.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest is Jenny Chen. She's talking about her son Jason. He likes to draw. What other things does Jason like to draw?
Jenny: He likes to draw houses. First he draws a large square. That's the house. Then he draws a triangle on top of the house.
Kathy: The roof.
Jenny: Yes. Then he draws two squares for windows. And a rectangle for the door. Sometimes he draws a small circle... for the doorknob.
Kathy: Can I see some of his pictures?
Jenny: OK. I'll bring them with me next time I come to your show.

comprehensionitem.question: What does Jason like to draw?
What shape does Jason use to draw the roof?
What shape is good for drawing a book, a credit card, or a door?

grammaritem.question: What other things ____ Jason like to draw?
First he draws a square. ____ he draws a triangle.
Sometimes he _____ a small circle for the doorknob.

mainlistitem.desc: I ride my bike to work.
mainlistitem.title: Unit 6: I ride my bike to work.

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Mike Johnson. Hello, Mike. Welcome to New Dynamic English.
Mike: Hello, Kathy. Thanks for inviting me.
Kathy: Can you tell us a little about yourself?
Mike: Well, I'm twenty-three years old... and I live in San Francisco. I work for Stagecoach Bank in downtown San Francisco. I'm an accountant. I work in the loans department.
Kathy: Do you live near your office?
Mike: No, I live about five miles away, on the other side of San Francisco.
Kathy: How do you get to work? Do you drive?
Mike: No, I don't. I don't have a car. I ride my bike to work.
Kathy: Really?
Mike: Yes, it's much cheaper than driving a car. And it's faster than taking the bus. It's great exercise, too. And it's much better for the environment!

comprehensionitem.question: What does Mike do?
option: He works in a department store.

comprehensionitem.question: How does Mike get to work?
What does Mike think about taking a bus to work?
option: It's not as fast as riding his bike.
It's faster than riding his bike.
It's more expensive than driving his car.
comprehensionitem.answer: It's not as fast as riding his bike.

grammaritem.question: How do you ___ to work?
Riding a bike is much _______ than driving a car.
And it's ____ better for the environment.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Mike Johnson. Mike works for a bank in San Francisco. You said you ride your bike to work. Do you think more people should ride their bikes to work?
Mike: Yes, I do. I think more people should ride bikes.
Kathy: Why?

Mike: For one thing, it would help the environment. Cars are the major cause of air pollution in San Francisco. If more people rode bikes, there would be fewer cars on the road. There would be less air pollution. And riding a bike is a great way to save money. It's very expensive to own and drive a car. And if you ride a bike, you don't have to pay for parking. And parking is very expensive in San Francisco.
Kathy: If you can find a parking space!
Mike: That's right!

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0506B_Q1.mp3|What is the major cause of air pollution in San Francisco?
NDE0506B_Q2.mp3|What would happen if more people rode bikes?
option: There would be fewer cars on the road.
There would be more air pollution.
It would be harder to find a parking space.
comprehensionitem.answer: There would be fewer cars on the road.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0506B_Q3.mp3|What is one advantage of riding a bike in San Francisco?
option: You don't have to pay for parking.
It is more expensive than driving a car.
It's not as fast as taking the bus.
comprehensionitem.answer: You don't have to pay for parking.

grammaritem.answer: Do you think more people should ride their bikes to work?
If more people rode bikes, there would be fewer cars on the road.
If you ride a bike, you don't have to pay for parking.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Is it safe to ride your bike on the streets of San Francisco?
Mike: Well, that's a difficult question. There's a lot of traffic, and sometimes there are accidents.
Kathy: Is the city government doing anything for bike riders... to make bike riding safer?

Mike: Well, last year they made bike lanes along some of the major streets. But I think they should do more. They should stop all automobile traffic on some streets. Some streets should be for bicycles only. Then it would be much safer to ride bikes.

comprehensionitem.question: Is it safe to ride a bicycle on the streets of San Francisco?
option: Not always. Sometimes there are accidents.
comprehensionitem.answer: Not always. Sometimes there are accidents.

comprehensionitem.question: What did the San Francisco government do to make the streets safer for bike riders?
option: They added bike lanes along some of the major streets.
They stopped all automobile traffic on some streets.
They added bike lanes to all San Francisco streets.
comprehensionitem.answer: They added bike lanes along some of the major streets.

comprehensionitem.question: How does Mike feel about the actions of the city government?
option: He feels that they should do more.
He feels that they didn't do anything.
He feels that they did too much.
comprehensionitem.answer: He feels that they should do more.

grammaritem.question: I think that they should __ more to help bike riders.
They should ____ all automobile traffic on some streets.
Some streets _________ for bicycles only.

lessonitem.name: Lesson Bonus
lessonitem.title: Lesson Bonus
viewscript: Kent: This is the New Dynamic English Man on the Street, Kent Moss. With me is Betty Li. Betty, may I ask why you're carrying that mirror?
Betty: I'm going to put it in my living room.
Kent: So your guests can look at their hair?
Betty: No! I'm putting it in my living room to bring me money.
Kent: How can a mirror bring you money?
Betty: I read a book about Feng Shui.
Kent: Feng Shui?
Betty: Yes, Feng Shui is the Chinese art of putting things in the best places in your house.
Kent: Hmmm! I see you're also carrying two red candles.
Betty: I'm going to put them in my bedroom.
Kent: To bring you money?
Betty: No! To bring me love!
Kent: Love! Feng Shui can bring love?
Betty: Certainly! It can bring you happiness, health, money and love!
Kent: Wow! Can I buy that mirror?
Betty: I'm sorry. It's not for sale.

comprehensionitem.question: What is Feng Shui?
option: the Chinese art of putting things in the best places
the Chinese art of preparing food
the Chinese art of building houses
comprehensionitem.answer: the Chinese art of putting things in the best places

comprehensionitem.question: Where will Betty put the mirror?
What are the two red candles for?

grammaritem.question: I'm _______ it in my living room to bring me money.
How can a mirror _____ you money?
I'm going ______ the candles in my bedroom.

mainlistitem.desc: How long will you stay in Washington?
mainlistitem.title: Unit 7: How long will you stay in Washington?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Hi, Max.
Max: Hi, Kathy.
Kathy: You look happy.
Max: Yes, next week I'm going to Boston to attend my sister's wedding.
Kathy: That sounds like fun. Are you going to fly to Boston?
Max: Well, last week I tried to buy a ticket, but the flight was full.
Kathy: Oh, that's too bad.
Max: It's OK. Yesterday my travel agent called me. She told me that there was space on the flight.
Kathy: Great.
Max: Yes. I'm going to get the ticket tomorrow.
Kathy: Well, today's guest is Henry Thornton, and he's going to talk about his travel plans.
Max: Henry Thornton? He's the businessman from Seattle.
Kathy: That's right.

comprehensionitem.question: How is Max going to get to Boston?
option: He's going to take the train.

comprehensionitem.question: Why couldn't he get a ticket last week?
option: He didn't have a travel agent.

comprehensionitem.question: Why did his travel agent call him yesterday?
option: to tell him that there was space on the flight
to tell him that the flight was cancelled
to tell him that the flight was full
comprehensionitem.answer: to tell him that there was space on the flight

grammaritem.question: Next week I'm _____ to Boston to attend my sister's wedding.
Last week I _____ to buy a ticket, but the flight was full.
She told me that _________ space on the flight.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Henry Thornton. Welcome back to our show, Mr. Thornton.
Henry: It's nice to be here.
Kathy: Are you here in Washington on business?
Henry: I'm here to meet with my Congressman.
Kathy: Your Congressman?
Henry: Yes, I'm going to meet with him this afternoon.
Kathy: What are you going to talk about?
Henry: We're going to talk about my plans for a new factory.
Kathy: How long will the meeting last?
Henry: I think it'll probably last... for about an hour.
Kathy: And what will you do after that?
Henry: I'll go back to my hotel, and then I'll go out to dinner with my lawyer. We'll probably go to a very nice restaurant.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0507B_Q1.mp3|Why is Henry in Washington?
option: to eat at a very nice restaurant

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0507B_Q2.mp3|How long will the meeting last?
option: to talk about a new factory

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0507B_Q3.mp3|What is Henry going to do this evening?
option: He'll have dinner with his lawyer.
He'll stay in his hotel room.
comprehensionitem.answer: He'll have dinner with his lawyer.

grammaritem.answer: I'm going to meet with him this afternoon.
How long will the meeting last?
I'll go out to dinner with my lawyer.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Mr. Thornton, how long do you plan to stay in Washington?
Henry: I'll be here until tomorrow afternoon, and then I'm going to go to Chicago.
Kathy: Chicago? When will you get to Chicago?
Henry: Well, my flight leaves Washington at one o'clock tomorrow afternoon. I'll arrive in Chicago around three o'clock.
Kathy: And when will you fly back to Seattle?
Henry: I'll fly back to Seattle the day after tomorrow, in the afternoon.
Kathy: So you'll only stay in Chicago for one day?
Henry: Well, actually, I'll be there for two days and one night.

comprehensionitem.question: When will Henry leave for Chicago?
When will he fly back to Seattle?
option: at the end of the week

comprehensionitem.question: How long will he stay in Washington?
option: He's not sure how long he'll stay.

grammaritem.question: How long __ you plan to stay in Chicago?
My flight ______ Washington at 1:00 tomorrow afternoon.
I'll fly back to Seattle the day _______________.

mainlistitem.desc: He's going to build a birdhouse.
mainlistitem.title: Unit 8: He's going to build a birdhouse.

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Diane Owens. Welcome back, Diane.
Diane: It's nice to see you again, Kathy.
Kathy: Your husband Dick drives a taxi, doesn't he?
Diane: That's right. He's a taxi driver.
Kathy: Does he work every day? Seven days a week?
Diane: Yes, he does. On weekdays, he works from ten in the morning until four in the afternoon. And on weekends, he works in the evening... from seven until one or two at night.
Kathy: Does he like his job?
Diane: Yes, he does. He meets lots of interesting people. And he enjoys driving!

comprehensionitem.question: What does Diane's husband do?
What is his work schedule?
option: He works seven days a week.
comprehensionitem.answer: He works seven days a week.

comprehensionitem.question: When does he work in the evening?

grammaritem.question: Your husband Dick drives a taxi, _______ he?
On weekdays, he works from 10:00 in the morning ________ 4:00 in the afternoon.
He meets lots of ___________ people.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Diane Owens. She's talking about her husband, Dick.
Kathy: Does Dick have any hobbies?
Diane: Well, he loves to build things. For example, this weekend he's going to build a birdhouse.
Kathy: A birdhouse? Tell me about it.
Diane: Well... First he'll make the walls, the floor, and the roof.
Kathy: Will he use wood?
Diane: Yes, he will. Wood is the best material for a birdhouse. After he makes the walls, he'll make a large hole in the front wall.
Kathy: So that the birds can go in and out?
Diane: That's right. He'll also make small holes in all the walls-for air.
Kathy: I see.
Diane: And he'll make holes in the floor so that water can go out.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0508B_Q1.mp3|What is Dick going to build?
NDE0508B_Q2.mp3|What material will he use?
NDE0508B_Q3.mp3|Why will he make holes in the floor?
option: So that water can go out.
So that the birds can go in and out.
So that air can come in.
comprehensionitem.answer: So that water can go out.

grammaritem.answer: This weekend he's going to build a birdhouse.
Wood is the best material for a birdhouse.
After he makes the walls, he'll make a large hole in the front wall.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Diane Owens. Will Dick paint the birdhouse?
Diane: He'll paint the outside of the birdhouse. But he won't paint the inside.
Kathy: He won't paint the inside? Why not?
Diane: Paint has chemicals that can hurt the birds. So he won't paint the inside where the birds will live.
Kathy: What color will he paint the birdhouse?
Diane: He'll paint it green.
Kathy: Where will he put the birdhouse?
Diane: He'll put it in a tree in our backyard. Birds like to build their nests in trees. So that's where we'll put our birdhouse.

comprehensionitem.question: What color will Dick paint the birdhouse?
Why won't he paint the inside of the birdhouse?
option: Because chemicals in the paint can hurt the birds.
Because no one can see inside the birdhouse.
comprehensionitem.answer: Because chemicals in the paint can hurt the birds.

comprehensionitem.question: Where will he put the birdhouse?
option: on the roof of his house

grammaritem.question: Paint has chemicals ____ can hurt the birds.
What color ____ he paint the birdhouse?
Birds like ________ their nests in trees.

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Maria Alvarez. She manages a women's clothing store in San Jose, California. How's business, Maria?
Maria: Good. Very good. In fact, next month we're going to open up a new store.
Kathy: A new store? What kind of store will it be?
Maria: It'll be a men's clothing store. We'll sell all kinds of men's clothing-shirts, ties, shoes, etc.
Kathy: How many people will work in the new store?
Maria: There will be five full-time employees, and some part-time workers.
Kathy: Will the store be open in the evening?
Maria: No, it won't. It'll close at six o'clock.

comprehensionitem.question: What is Maria going to do next month?
option: She's going to open a men's clothing store.
She's going to open a new women's clothing store.
She's going to start a new job.
comprehensionitem.answer: She's going to open a men's clothing store.

comprehensionitem.question: How many people will work in the new store?
option: 5 full-time employees, plus some part-time workers
comprehensionitem.answer: 5 full-time employees, plus some part-time workers

comprehensionitem.question: How late will the store be open?
option: It's only open in the morning.

grammaritem.question: Next month we're going _______ a new store.
How many people _________ in the new store?
Will the store _______ in the evening?

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Maria Alvarez. She's talking about a new men's clothing store that is going to open next month. Who will manage the new store? Will you?
Maria: No, I won't. I'm too busy. I can't manage two stores. We'll have to hire a manager.
Kathy: What kind of person will you hire?
Maria: We're looking for someone who knows a lot about men's clothing. And we want someone who is good with people.
Kathy: That makes sense.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0509B_Q1.mp3|Who will manage the new store?
option: They will hire a new manager.
The store will be small and won't need a manager.
comprehensionitem.answer: They will hire a new manager.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0509B_Q2.mp3|Why won't Maria manage the new store herself?
option: She's too busy to manage two stores.
She doesn't know much about men's clothing.
She doesn't like the new store.
comprehensionitem.answer: She's too busy to manage two stores.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0509B_Q3.mp3|What kind of person will they hire?
option: Someone who is good with people.
Someone who knows a lot about women's clothing.
Someone who is managing a clothing store.
comprehensionitem.answer: Someone who is good with people.

grammaritem.answer: We'll have to hire a manager.
We want someone who is good with people.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Maria Alvarez. She's talking about a new store that is going to open next month. Maria, do you think you'll open other stores in the future?
Maria: We may open a children's clothing store, but I'm not sure. Or perhaps we'll open another women's clothing store.
Kathy: Will you open stores in other states?
Maria: I don't think so. We probably won't open any stores outside of California.

comprehensionitem.question: Is Maria going to open more stores in the future?
option: Yes. She will definitely open more stores.
No. She won't open any more stores.

comprehensionitem.question: What are her plans for opening a children's clothing store?
Where are Maria's stores?

grammaritem.question: Do you think ______ open other stores in the future?
We ___ open a children's store, but I'm not sure.
We probably _____ open any stores out of California.

lessonitem.name: Lesson Bonus
lessonitem.title: Lesson Bonus
viewscript: Kent: Hello. This is Kent Moss from Washington, D.C. With me is Madame Roux. She's a fortune teller. Madame Roux, why are you holding my hand?
Roux: I'm reading your future.
Kent: And what can you see?
Roux: I see that you will have a long life.
Kent: That's good news!
Roux: I also see that you will be successful and make a lot of money.
Kent: Great!
Roux: You will also marry a beautiful woman.
Kent: Wait a minute! I'm already married!
Roux: Does your wife have blond hair?
Kent: No... she has black hair.
Roux: Oh. Let me see your other hand.

comprehensionitem.question: What is Madame Roux?
Which of these does Madame Roux not see in Kent's future?
What color hair does Kent's wife have?

grammaritem.question: Why ___ you holding my hand?
I see that you will ____ a long life.
I'm already _______.

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Ellen Williams. Hello, Ellen.
Ellen: Nice to see you again, Kathy.
Kathy: You're going to talk to us today about water pollution.
Ellen: Yes. Do you know the biggest cause of water pollution in the United States?
Kathy: Is it... factories?
Ellen: No, it isn't. It's farming.
Kathy: Farming?
Ellen: Yes. Farming is the biggest cause of water pollution in the United States.
Kathy: How does farming cause water pollution?
Ellen: Most farmers use pesticides to kill insects. If these pesticides get into our water, they can cause water pollution. Water pollution can cause health problems.
Kathy: That's really true.

comprehensionitem.question: What's the biggest cause of water pollution in the United States?
Why do farmers use pesticides?
option: to keep animals away from crops

comprehensionitem.question: Why do you think farmers need to control insects?

grammaritem.question: Farming is __________ cause of water pollution in the United States.
How does farming _____ water pollution?
If pesticides get into our water, they can _____ water pollution.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Ellen Williams. She's talking about farmers and water pollution. How can farmers stop water pollution?
Ellen: First of all, they can use fewer pesticides.
Kathy: But if farmers don't use pesticides, won't insects destroy their crops?
Ellen: Maybe, but there are other ways to control insects. One way is to use natural products. These products will kill insects but they won't hurt people.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0510B_Q1.mp3|How does Ellen think farmers can stop water pollution?
option: They can stop insects from destroying their crops.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0510B_Q2.mp3|What may happen if farmers don't use pesticides?
option: Farmers won't be able to control insects.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0510B_Q3.mp3|What is an advantage of using natural products to control insects?
option: Natural products can kill insects without hurting people.
Natural products do not harm insects.
Natural products are less expensive than pesticides.
comprehensionitem.answer: Natural products can kill insects without hurting people.

grammaritem.answer: Ellen thinks that farmers can use fewer pesticides.
If farmers don't use pesticides, won't insects destroy their crops?
Natural products will kill insects but they won't hurt people.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Now it's time for a phone call. Hello. You're on the air with New Dynamic English.
Margo: My name is Margo. I'm from Sacramento, California. I don't buy food from farmers who use pesticides.
Kathy: So you'll only eat organic food, food without pesticides?
Margo: That's right. Organic food is better for my health and for my children's health. And organic fruits and vegetables taste much better than other fruits and vegetables.
Kathy: Thank you, Margo, for your opinion.

comprehensionitem.question: What is organic food?
option: food that is grown without pesticides
comprehensionitem.answer: food that is grown without pesticides

comprehensionitem.question: What kind of food does Margo buy?
option: She buys food from farmers who use pesticides.

comprehensionitem.question: Which of these is not a reason why Margo buys organic food?
option: It is better for her health.

grammaritem.question: I don't ___ food from farmers who use pesticides.
Organic food is better for my health and my __________ health.
Organic vegetables _____ much better than other vegetables.

mainlistitem.title: Unit 11: Will you accept the job?

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Chris Scott. Welcome back, Chris.
Chris: Thank you.
Kathy: How are things?
Chris: Very interesting, actually. You know, I dance with a ballet company in Chicago.
Kathy: Yes.
Chris: Well, this morning I had an interview with a dance company here in Washington, DC.
Kathy: Really? How did it go?
Chris: I think I did OK.
Kathy: Do you think they'll offer you a job?
Chris: Well, I think so.
Kathy: If they offer you a job, will you accept?

Chris: I'm not sure what I'll do. I like living in Chicago. I have a lot of friends there. And I love living with my sister Sara. If I accept the job, I'll have to move to Washington. I'll miss my sister and I'll miss all my friends in Chicago.
Kathy: That sounds like a difficult decision.
Chris: Yes. However, they may not offer me the job. And then I won't have to make a decision.

comprehensionitem.question: What did Chris do this morning?
option: She had an interview for a new job.
comprehensionitem.answer: She had an interview for a new job.

comprehensionitem.question: Where will Chris live if she accepts the new job?
How does she feel about Chicago?
option: She doesn't want to move there.
She doesn't have any friends in Chicago.

grammaritem.question: Do you think they'll _____ you a job?
If I accept the job, I'll _______ move to Washington.
They _______ offer me the job.

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is Chris Scott. She lives in Chicago, but she may move to Washington, DC. Chris, which dance company is larger, the one in Chicago or the one here in Washington?
Chris: Well, the Chicago company is larger, but the Washington company is more famous. And the salaries are higher.
Kathy: So if you move to Washington, you'll make more money.
Chris: Yes, and more people will see me dance. I may even become famous.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0511B_Q1.mp3|Which dance company is more famous?
NDE0511B_Q2.mp3|Which dance company pays better?
NDE0511B_Q3.mp3|Is Chris going to move to Washington?

grammaritem.answer: The Washington company is more famous.
If you move to Washington, you'll make more money.
More people will see her dance if she moves to Washington.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: We're back with our guest, Chris Scott. You have a dog, don't you?
Chris: Yes, his name's Woody.
Kathy: If you move to Washington, will you bring Woody with you?

Chris: Of course! Wherever I go, Woody goes. I won't move to Washington without him! Now, when I go out of town, Sara stays with Woody. In Washington, I'll have to have a roommate. So that if I go out of town, somebody will stay with Woody. He gets very lonely. I once left him by himself all night and he ate my shoes.

comprehensionitem.question: Who is Woody?
Who stays with Woody when Chris goes out of town?
If Chris goes to Washington, will she take Woody with her?
option: She will, unless she has a roommate.

grammaritem.question: I won't move to Washington _______ him.
When I go out of town, Sara _____ with Woody.
I once left him __________ all night and he ate my shoes.

mainlistitem.title: Unit 12: I may take the train.

lessonitem.name: Lesson A
lessonitem.title: Lesson A
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is John Orwell. John is a well-known writer. Welcome to our show.
John: I'm pleased to be here.
Kathy: John, what are you working on now?
John: Well, I'm working on a new story that will appear on television next year.
Kathy: Wonderful! John, you live in England, don't you?
John: That's right. I live in Brighton. It's about an hour south of London by train. I'm here in Washington on vacation.
Kathy: Were you born in England?
John: No, I wasn't. I was born in the United States. I'm an American citizen.
Kathy: Do you think you'll ever move back to the US?
John: I don't know. I like living in England. But I may move back to the US sometime. Or maybe I'll move to another country. There are many possibilities.

comprehensionitem.question: Where does John live?
Why did he come to Washington?
option: He's going to be on television.

comprehensionitem.question: Where was he born?

grammaritem.question: I'm working on a new story that ___________ on TV next year.
____ you born in England?
Do you think ______ ever move back to the US?

lessonitem.name: Lesson B
lessonitem.title: Lesson B
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is John Orwell. Where will you go after you leave Washington?
John: I'm going to visit some friends in San Francisco.
Kathy: Will you fly?
John: I'm not sure what I'll do. In fact, if I have time, I may take the train.
Kathy: That sounds interesting.
John: Yes, if I take the train, I'll be able to see the countryside. And on the train you can meet some interesting people.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0512B_Q1.mp3|After he leaves Washington, where will John go?
NDE0512B_Q2.mp3|How will John get to San Francisco?
option: He has decided to take the train.

comprehensionitem.question: NDE0512B_Q3.mp3|How will he travel if he has enough time?

grammaritem.answer: Where will you go after you leave Washington?
I'm not sure what I'll do.
If I take the train, I'll be able to see the countryside.

lessonitem.name: Lesson C
lessonitem.title: Lesson C
viewscript: Kathy: Our guest today is John Orwell. How long will you stay in San Francisco?
John: I'll probably stay there for about a week.
Kathy: And then what?
John: Then I'll fly back to England. I'll try to get a non-stop flight.
Kathy: That's a long flight, isn't it?
John: Yes. It takes ten hours to fly from San Francisco to London. If I leave on a Saturday afternoon, I'll arrive in London on Sunday morning.
Kathy: So I'm sure you'll be tired.
John: I'm sure I will. There's an eight-hour time difference between San Francisco and London.

comprehensionitem.question: How long will John stay in San Francisco?
How long does it take to fly from San Francisco to London?
If he leaves on a Saturday afternoon, when will he arrive?

grammaritem.question: How long ____ you stay in San Francisco?
I'll ______ get a non-stop flight.
It ________ 10 hours to fly from San Francisco to London.

lessonitem.name: Lesson Bonus
lessonitem.title: Lesson Bonus
viewscript: Kent: This is the New Dynamic English Man on the Street, Kent Moss. With me is Agent Johnson of the FBI. Agent Johnson, can you tell me what you're doing here?
Johnson: I'm waiting for someone.
Kent: A criminal? Is a criminal going to come out of that apartment?
Johnson: Possibly.
Kent: If he comes out, will you arrest him?
Johnson: I may.
Kent: If he has a gun, will you shoot him?
Johnson: Perhaps.
Kent: Look! That man walking towards us ... is he the one you're waiting for?
Johnson: Yes, he is.
Kent: He looks very dangerous.
Johnson: Dad... hi!

comprehensionitem.question: What is the FBI [the Federal Bureau of Investigation]?
option: It protects the United States against crime.
It makes the laws of the United States.
comprehensionitem.answer: It protects the United States against crime.

comprehensionitem.question: Who is Agent Johnson?
Who is Agent Johnson waiting for?

grammaritem.question: Can you tell me what ______ doing here?
__ a criminal going to come out of that apartment?
If a criminal comes out, ____ you arrest him?
